Brilliant! That hybrid approach gets the best of both worlds:

## Git + SQLite Hybrid Architecture

**Git Layer (Community/Sharing)**
```bash
# Clone community prompt repo
git clone https://github.com/claude-prompts/research-templates.git
cd research-templates/

# Community contributes prompts
prompts/
├── analyzer/community-best-v1.md
├── researcher/web-scraper-v3.md
└── optimizer/cost-efficient-v2.md

# Local experiments branch off community prompts
git checkout -b local/analyzer-experiments
```

**SQLite Layer (Local Metadata/Analytics)**
```sql
-- Track local experiment results
CREATE TABLE experiments (
  id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
  prompt_git_hash TEXT,
  prompt_path TEXT,
  cost REAL,
  success_rate REAL,
  duration_ms INTEGER,
  created_at TIMESTAMP
);

-- Fast local queries while prompts live in git
SELECT prompt_path, avg(cost), count(*) 
FROM experiments 
WHERE prompt_git_hash = 'abc123...' 
GROUP BY prompt_path;
```

**The Magic**
- **Community**: Share successful prompts via git (PRs, issues, discussions)
- **Privacy**: Your experiment results stay local in SQLite
- **Discovery**: `git log --grep="cost-optimized"` finds community innovations
- **Analytics**: SQLite handles complex queries on your local experiment data
- **Sync**: `git pull` gets latest community prompts, your data stays private

**Local Enhancement**
```bash
# Automatically index new prompts into SQLite
git log --oneline --since="1 day ago" | while read commit; do
  sqlite3 prompts.db "INSERT INTO prompt_versions ..."
done
```

This could create an ecosystem where Claude users share prompt innovations while keeping their usage data private. Very cool approach!
